{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|(33342) 1998 WT|24}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|(33342) 1998 WT|24}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = 33342 1998 WT24.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Tracks of asteroid {{mp|1998 WT|24}} | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research|LINEAR]] | discovery_site = [[Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site|Lincoln Lab's ETS]] | discovered = 25 November 1998 | mpc_name = (33342) {{mp|1998 WT|24}} | alt_names = {{mp|1998 WT|24}} | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Aten asteroid|Aten]]{{·}}[[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 28 June 2009 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2455010.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 18.98 yr (6,933 days) | aphelion = 1.0187 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.4182 AU | semimajor = 0.7185 AU | eccentricity = 0.4179 | period = 0.61 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (222 days) | mean_anomaly = 344.05[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|1.6184|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 7.3419° | asc_node = 82.000° | arg_peri = 167.30° | moid = 0.0097 AU (3.8 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]]) | mean_diameter = {{val|0.35|0.04}} km
0.410 km {{small|(taken)}}
{{val|0.415|0.040}} km | rotation = {{val|3.6970|0.0002}} [[Hour|h]]
{{val|3.697|0.0006}} h{{efn|name=lightcurve-plots-Warner}}
{{val|3.697|}} h
{{val|3.6977|0.0023}} h{{efn|name=lcdb-Pravec-2001}}
{{val|3.698|}} h{{efn|name=lcdb-Robinson-2011}}
{{val|3.7|0.1}} h | albedo = {{val|0.34|0.2}}
{{val|0.56|0.2}}
{{val|0.75|0.35}} | spectral_type = [[E-type asteroid|E]] {{·}}[[S-type asteroid|S]]  | abs_magnitude = 17.9{{·}}{{val|18.5|0.3}}{{·}}18.69{{·}}{{val|18.69|0.3}} }} '''{{mp|(33342) 1998 WT|24}}''' is a bright, sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] (PHA) of the [[Aten asteroid|Aten group]], located in [[Venus]]'s zone of influence that has frequent close encounters with [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]], Venus, and [[Earth]]. It made a close approach to Earth on 11 December 2015, passing at a distance of about 4.2 million kilometers (2.6 million miles, 11 lunar distances) and reaching about [[apparent magnitude]] 11. The asteroid was discovered on November 25, 1998, by [[LINEAR]] about four months after a close encounter with the planet Mercury (about 0.047 [[astronomical unit|AU]]). It measures approximately 400 meters in diameter. It is also one of the best studied PHAs and was the 10th Aten asteroid to be [[Minor planet designation|numbered]]. == Classification and orbit == [[File:(33342) 1998 WT24 bistatic radar image.gif|left|250px|thumb|Radar observation during 2001 encounter]] {{mp|1998 WT|24}} orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.42–1.02 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 7 months (222 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 0.72 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.42 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 7[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. === Low aphelion === At the time of its discovery, astronomers were trying to find the first [[Apohele asteroid]] (one that is always closer to the [[Sun]] than Earth). All asteroids known at the time that got closer to the Sun than Earth also crossed Earth's orbit. Earlier that year, [[David J. Tholen]] claimed to have spotted the first Apohele asteroid, which was dubbed {{mpl|1998 DK|36}}. However, the object was lost without being confirmed. Thus, [[1993 DA]] remained the asteroid with the lowest known [[aphelion]] at 1.023 AU. When {{mp|1998 WT|24}} was discovered, it was found to have a slightly smaller aphelion (1.019 AU) than 1993 DA, and was thus the closest thing to an Apohele asteroid known at the time. It lost its smallest aphelion title almost immediately when {{mpl|(415713) 1998 XX|2}} was discovered only a few weeks later (aphelion = 1.014 AU). Asteroids with even smaller aphelions were discovered until February 2003, when finally, an asteroid with an aphelion smaller than 1.000 AU was discovered. This was [[163693 Atira]], the first confirmed Apohele asteroid. === Venus zone of influence === {{mp|1998 WT|24}} was the second asteroid discovered to be close enough to [[Venus]] as to be within the major planet's zone of influence. It is located at about the inner edge of the zone, while [[(99907) 1989 VA]], the first asteroid discovered there, is at about the outer edge. It is possible for planets to capture asteroids located in their sphere of influences into co-orbital relationships such as [[Trojan asteroid|Trojan]] and [[horseshoe orbit|horseshoe]] asteroids. Because of its frequent close encounters with Mercury and Earth, however, it may prove difficult for Venus to keep {{mp|1998 WT|24}} in a co-orbital relationship for any length of time. Of the six objects in Venus's zone of influence, only one ({{mpl|2002 VE|68}}) is currently a co-orbital. === Record close encounter === {{mp|1998 WT|24}} is a [[potentially hazardous asteroid]]. That means its orbit takes it very close to Earth and if it were to collide with our planet, it would cause devastation on at least a regional scale. On December 16, 2001, it became the first PHA to be observed passing within 5 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|Lunar Distances]] (the average distance between Earth and the [[Moon]]) from Earth. Other asteroids have come closer, and numerous have even come closer than the Moon, but these have all been small asteroids, incapable of causing much damage to the planet, or much concern. The 2001 encounter was the closest known approach to Earth any PHA had made since {{mpl|(192642) 1999 RD|32}} passed by on August 27, 1969. However, {{mp|1999 RD|32}} was not discovered until September 1999 many years after its closest approach, so no one knew about {{mp|1999 RD|32}} in 1969. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float: left; margin: 0 20px 0 0; font-size: 0.9em;" |+Notable close-approaches to Earth |- ! Date !! Distance from Earth |- | 1908-12-16 || {{convert|0.00907|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} |- | 1956-12-16 || {{convert|0.009054|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} |- | 2001-12-16 || {{convert|0.012485|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} |- | 2099-12-18 || {{convert|0.012640|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} |} In September 2004, the well known PHA [[4179 Toutatis]] came about 4 Lunar Distances from Earth. Due to its diameter being over ten times larger (5.7 km) and its closer approach, Toutatis at its closest (mag 8.9) was about half an [[apparent magnitude]] brighter than {{mp|1998 WT|24}} was at its closest (mag 9.5). However, Toutatis arrived during a full moon, and thus {{mp|1998 WT|24}}'s 2001 encounter is still the most easily observed flyby of an asteroid in history. It also made {{mp|1998 WT|24}} the first [[Near-Earth asteroid]] observed to be brighter than magnitude 10. {{clear|left}} {{Large near earth asteroid flybys 5LD}} === Frequent inner-planet encounters === {{mp|1998 WT|24}} is a [[Mercury-crosser asteroid]], a [[Venus-crosser asteroid]], and an [[Earth-crosser asteroid]]. Because of its relatively low inclination (7.34°), it is able to come close to each of these planets. Its orbit takes it within 0.021 AU of Mercury's orbit, 0.0368 AU of Venus's orbit, and 0.00989 AU of Earth's orbit. It makes frequent encounters with these inner planets. The last time it came close to Mercury, Venus and Earth was 2010, 1977, and November 12, 2004 respectively. The most recent close approach to Earth was on 11 December 2015 at about 4.2 million kilometers (2.6 million miles, 11 lunar distances). The next visit of the asteroid to Earth's neighborhood will be on 11 November 2018, when it will make a relatively distant pass at about 20 million kilometers (12.5 million miles, 52 lunar distances). These encounters [[Perturbation (astronomy)|perturb]] its orbit parameters slightly, and each pass reduces its inclination further. == Physical characteristics == During its close encounters in 2001 and 2015, astronomers were able to make radar images of its surface and determine physical properties that remain unknown for most asteroids. According to the ExploreNEOs Warm Spitzer Exploration Science program, {{mp|1998 WT|24}} is a bright [[E-type asteroid]] with an exceptionally high albedo of {{val|0.75|0.35}}. === Diameter and albedo === {{mp|1998 WT|24}} measures between 350 and 415 meters in diameter and its surface has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] between 0.34 and 0.75.{{efn|name=lcdb-Robinson-2011}} The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' an albedo of 0.34 and takes a diameter of 410 meters based on an [[absolute magnitude]] of 18.69. The asteroid is modestly elongated, approximately 420 × 330 meters.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} === Rotation period === Several rotational [[lightcurve]]s of {{mp|1998 WT|24}} have been obtained from radiometric and photometric observations.{{efn|name=lcdb-Pravec-2001}}{{efn|name=lcdb-Robinson-2011}} Lightcurve analysis gave a consolidated [[rotation period]] of 3.697 hours with a brightness amplitude between 0.19 and 0.65 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3]]}}).{{efn|name=lightcurve-plots-Warner}} == Future flyby candidate == {{mp|1998 WT|24}} has an orbit that not only crosses Earth's orbit, but is roughly parallel to it at its furthest. This means that during favourable years it is easy to reach from Earth. Several times this decade, it will be an easier target than Earth's own Moon. It is high on the list of possible Near-Earth Asteroid targets for future flybys, landings, mining, or orbit manipulations. == Numbering and naming == This [[minor planet]] was [[Minor planet designation|numbered]] by the [[Minor Planet Center]] on 28 January 2002. As of 2018, it has not been [[List of named minor planets (alphabetical)|named]]. == See also == * [[List of asteroid close approaches to Earth in 2015]] == Notes == {{notelist|refs= {{efn|name=lcdb-Robinson-2011|1=Robinson (2011) web: rotation period {{val|3.698}} hours with a brightness amplitude of {{val|0.26}} mag. Quality Code of 3. Summary figures for (33342) at the [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=33342%7C LCDB]}} {{efn|name=lcdb-Pravec-2001|1=Pravec (2001) web. Observations from December 2001. Rotation period {{val|3.6977|0.0023}} hours with a brightness amplitude of {{val|0.28}} mag. Quality Code of 3. Summary figures for (33342) at the [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=33342%7C LCDB] and [http://www.asu.cas.cz/~ppravec/neo.htm Pravec, P.; Wolf, M.; Sarounova, L. (2001)], see [http://www.asu.cas.cz/~ppravec/newres.htm Ondrejov data] obtained by the NEO Photometric Program and collaborating projects }} {{efn|name=lightcurve-plots-Warner|1=Several [http://www.planetarysciences.org/plots/BDW/33342_1998WT24_2015-11-22.PNG lightcurve plots of (33342)] obtained at the Center for Solar System Studies by [[Brian D. Warner|B. D. Warner]] (2015).}} }} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-11-17 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 33342 (1998 WT24) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2033342 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 30 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = (33342) 1998 WT24 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=33342 |accessdate = 30 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = MPC/MPO/MPS Archive |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/ECS/MPCArchive/MPCArchive_TBL.html |accessdate = 24 February 2018}} {{cite web |date=17 December 2015 |title=Asteroid Looks Even Better Second Time Around |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4800 |publisher=NASA JPL |accessdate=18 December 2015}} {{cite web |date = 2001-12-14 |title = Bright Asteroid |url = http://science1.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2001/ast14dec_1/ |publisher = NASA Science |accessdate = 2014-02-26 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140302173107/http://science1.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2001/ast14dec_1/ |archive-date = 2014-03-02 |dead-url = yes |df = }} {{cite web |title=(33342) 1998WT24 Ephemerides for December 2015 |publisher=NEODyS-2 (Near Earth Objects - Average Albedo by Taxonomic Complex in the Near-Earth Asteroid Population |url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0004-6256/142/3/85/pdf |journal = The Astronomical Journal |volume = 142 |issue = 3 |page = 12 |bibcode = 2011AJ....142...85T |doi = 10.1088/0004-6256/142/3/85 |access-date= 30 January 2018}} }} == External links == * [http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/images/1998wt24.html IMAGES OF ASTEROID 1998 WT24] - [[NASA]] * [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103508000729 Physical properties of near-Earth Asteroid (33342) 1998 WT24] - shape model of 1998 WT24 from Goldstone and Arecibo radar imaging 2001 * [http://www.cplire.ru/html/ra&sr/sr/33342/index.html Radar Investigations of Asteroid 33342 (1998 WT24) in December 2001 with Evpatoria-Medichina and Goldstone-Medichina Bistatic Systems] * {{JPL small body|id=33342}} {{Minor planets navigator | |number=33342 |PageName={{mp|(33342) 1998 WT|24}} |}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{2015 in space}} {{DEFAULTSORT:033342}} [[Category:Aten asteroids]] [[Category:Numbered minor planets]] [[Category:Discoveries by LINEAR]] [[Category:Radar-imaged asteroids]] [[Category:Potentially hazardous asteroids]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2015|20151211]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 1998|19981125]]

[[Asteroid color indices|U–B]] {{=}} 0.520  | abs_magnitude = 16.3{{·}}{{val|16.3|0.3}}{{·}}16.6{{·}}16.9{{·}}16.96 }} '''1566 Icarus''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɪ|k|ər|ə|s}} {{respell|IK|ə-rəs}}), provisional designation {{mp|1949 MA}}, is an extremely eccentric [[asteroid]], approximately 1.4 kilometers in diameter. It is a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]] and the lowest numbered [[potentially hazardous asteroid]]. In 1968, it became the first asteroid ever observed by radar. Its orbit brings it closer to the Sun than Mercury and further out than the orbit of Mars, which also makes it a [[List of Mercury-crossing minor planets|Mercury-]], [[List of Venus-crossing minor planets|Venus-]], and [[Mars-crosser]]. This stony asteroid and relatively [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)|fast rotator]] was discovered by German astronomer [[Walter Baade]] at the [[Palomar Observatory]], California, on 27 June 1949. It was named after the mythological boy [[Icarus]], who flew too close to the Sun. == Orbit and classification == [[File:1566 Icarus orbit.gif|thumb|left|Orbital diagram of ''Icarus'']] ''Icarus'' orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.2–2.0 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 1 years and 1 month (409 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.83 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 23[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with its official discovery observation at Palomar. At [[perihelion]], ''Icarus'' comes closer to the [[Sun]] than [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]], i.e. it is a [[Mercury-crossing asteroid]]. It is also a [[Venus-crosser asteroid|Venus]] and [[Mars-crosser asteroid|Mars-crosser]]. From 1949 until the discovery of [[3200 Phaethon]] in 1983, it was known as the asteroid that passed closest to the Sun. Since then hundreds of Mercury-crossers have been found, the closest ones are now being {{mpl|2005 HC|4}} and {{mpl|(394130) 2006 HY|51}} ''(also see {{section link|List of Mercury-crossing minor planets|List}})''. === Meteor shower === ''Icarus'' is thought to be the source of the [[Arietids]],[http://www.spaceweather.com/meteors/arietids.html Daylight Meteors: The Arietids @spaceweather.com] a strong daylight [[meteor shower]]. However other objects such as the short-period sun-grazing comet [[96P/Machholz]] are also possible candidates for the shower's origin.[https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8197785/ On the Association among Periodic Comet 96P/Machholz, Arietids, the Marsden Comet Group, and the Kracht Comet Group] === Close approaches === ''Icarus'' has an ''Earth [[minimum orbital intersection distance]]'' of {{convert|0.0352 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=on}}, which translates into 13.7 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]] (LD). This [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] makes close approaches to [[Earth]] in June at intervals of 9, 19, or 28 years. In 14 June 1968, it came as close as {{convert|0.042482 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=on}}, or 16 LD. During this approach, Icarus became the first minor planet to be observed using [[radar]], with measurements obtained at the [[Haystack Observatory]] and the [[Goldstone Tracking Station]]. The last close approach was on 16 June 2015, when ''Icarus'' passed Earth at {{convert|0.05383 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off}} or 22 LD. Before that, the previous close approach was on 11 June 1996, at {{convert|0.10119 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off}}, almost 40 times as far as the Moon. The next notably close approach will be on 13 June 2043, at {{convert|0.0586 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off}} from Earth. == Physical characteristics == Radiometric observation characterized ''Icarus'' as a stony [[S-type asteroid|S-type]] and [[Q-type asteroid]]. === Rotation period === Since 1968, several rotational [[lightcurve]]s of ''Icarus'' were obtained from photometric and radiometric observations. During the asteroid's close approach in June 2017, observations of the fast-moving object were taken by Italian astronomers Virginio Oldani and Federico Manzini, [[Brian D. Warner|Brian Warner]] at the Palmer Divide Station ({{small|[[IAU code#U82|U82]]}}) in California, and by Australian astronomers at the Darling Range and Blue Mountains Observatories ({{small|[[IAU code#Q68|Q68]]}}).{{efn|name=ligthcurve-plot-Warner}} Lightcurve analysis gave it a consolidated [[rotation period]] of 2.2726 hours with a brightness variation of 0.22 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3]]}}).{{efn|name=ligthcurve-plot-Warner}} ''Icarus'' is a relatively [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)|fast rotator]], near the threshold where non-solid [[rubble pile]]s fly apart. === Spin axis === In 2015, radiometric observations at the [[Goldstone Observatory]] in California found a [[Poles of astronomical bodies|spin axis]] of (270.0°, −81.0°) in [[Ecliptic coordinate system|ecliptic coordinates]] (λ, β). === Diameter and albedo === According to several radiometric and photometric observations, including the survey carried out by the [[NEOWISE]] mission of NASA's [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]], ''Icarus'' measures between 1.0 and 1.44 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] between 0.14 and 0.51.{{efn|name=Gehrels}} The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' adopts the radiometric results obtained at Goldstone Observatory in June 2015, which gave an albedo of 0.14 and a diameter of 1.44 kilometers based on an [[absolute magnitude]] of 16.96. Goldstone observations also gave the body's dimensions: 1.61 × 1.60 × 1.17 kilometers. == Naming == This [[minor planet]] was named after [[Icarus]], son of [[Daedalus]] ''(also see [[1864 Daedalus]])'' from [[Greek mythology]]. They attempted to escape prison by means of wings constructed from feathers and wax. Icarus ignored his father's instructions not to fly too close to the Sun. When the wax in his wings melted he fell into the sea and drowned. The naming was suggested by R. C. Cameron and Dr. Folkman. The official naming citation was published by the [[Minor Planet Center]] before November 1977 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 347}}). Both mythological figures are honored with the lunar craters ''[[Icarus (crater)|Icarus]]'' and ''[[Daedalus (crater)|Daedalus]]''. == Research interests == ''Icarus'' is being studied to better understand [[general relativity]], solar oblateness, and [[Yarkovsky effect|Yarkovsky drift]]. [[Apsidal precession#General relativity|Perihelion precession]], caused by general relativity, in the case of Icarus is 10.05 [[arcsecond]]s per [[Julian century]]. == Project Icarus == "Project Icarus" was a student project conducted at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] in the spring of 1967, to defend against risks from {{mp|1566 Icarus}}. This project was an assignment by Paul Sandorff for his group of Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate students in a systems engineering class to devise a plan to use rockets to deflect or destroy ''Icarus'' in the case that it was found to be on a collision course with planet Earth.Kleiman, Louis A., [http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=6840 ''Project Icarus: an MIT Student Project in Systems Engineering''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017105104/http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=6840 |date=October 17, 2007 }}, Cambridge, Massachusetts: MIT Press, 1968[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,843952,00.html "Systems Engineering: Avoiding an Asteroid"], ''Time'' magazine, June 16, 1967.Day, Dwayne A., [http://www.thespacereview.com/article/175/1 "Giant bombs on giant rockets: Project Icarus"], ''The Space Review'', Monday, July 5, 2004. [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine ran an article on the endeavor in June 1967 and the following year the student report was published as a book.[http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=6840 Project Icarus] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017105104/http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=6840 |date=October 17, 2007 }}, MIT Report No. 13, MIT Press 1968, edited by Louis A. Kleiman. "Interdepartmental Student Project in Systems Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Spring Term, 1967"; reissued 1979. In the course of their study the students visited the [[Kennedy Space Center]], Florida, where they were so impressed with the [[Vertical Assembly Building]] that they wrote of "the awesome reality" that had "completely erased" their doubts over using the technology associated with the [[Apollo program]] and [[Saturn (rocket family)|Saturn rockets]].{{cite web |author=David S. F. Portree |title=MIT Saves the World: Project Icarus (1967) |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2012/03/mit-saves-the-world-project-icarus-1967/ |publisher=Wired Science |accessdate=21 October 2013}} === In fiction === {{Further|Asteroids in fiction#Icarus}} The report later served as the basis and inspiration for the 1979 science fiction film ''[[Meteor (film)|Meteor]]''.[http://tech.mit.edu/archives/VOL_099/TECH_V099_S0470_P003.pdf "MIT Course precept for movie"], ''The Tech'', MIT, October 30, 1979 == Notes == {{notelist|refs= {{efn|name=Gehrels|1=Hazards due to Comets and Asteroids (1994), Ed. T. Gehrels, pp.540-543 at JPL's [https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2001566 SBDB]}} {{efn|name=ligthcurve-plot-Warner|1=[http://www.planetarysciences.org/plots/BDW/1566_ICARUS_2015-06-16.PNG Lightcurve plot of (1566) Icarus] by Brian Warner at [http://planetarysciences.org/ CS3]-PDS (2015). Summary figures at the [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=1566%7CIcarus LCDB]}} }} == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2015-07-31 last obs. {{Infobox planet | background = #FFC2E0 | name = 2009 RR | discovery_ref = | discoverer = [[Catalina Sky Survey]] ([[List of observatory codes#700–799|703]]) | discovered = 11 September 2009 | mpc_name = 2009 RR | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]  | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | observation_arc = 4 days
(last seen 2009) | aphelion = {{Convert|2.0753|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} | perihelion = {{Convert|0.75416|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | semimajor = {{Convert|1.4147|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | eccentricity = 0.46693 | period = 1.68 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (614.63 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 6.1464° | asc_node = 174.21° | mean_anomaly = 252.65[[Degree (angle)|°]] | arg_peri = 256.21° | dimensions = ~{{convert|26|m|sp=us}}
20–45 meters | mass = 2.4{{e|7}} kg (assumed) | magnitude = | abs_magnitude = 25.5 | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.58572|sup=ms}} /day (n) | uncertainty = 7 | moid = {{Convert|0.0028846|AU|km|abbr=on}} }} '''2009 RR''' micro-[[asteroid]], classified as [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]]. It was discovered on 11 September 2009 by the [[Catalina Sky Survey]] at an [[apparent magnitude]] of 19.5 using a {{convert|0.68|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[Schmidt–Cassegrain telescope]]. {{mp|2009 RR}} was the only asteroid discovered before 2014 that was predicted to potentially pass [[List of asteroid close approaches to Earth in 2014|inside the orbit of the Moon]] during 2014. The asteroid has an estimated diameter of {{convert|26|m|sp=us}} and is listed on the [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]]. It is not large enough to qualify as a [[potentially hazardous object]]. == Description == With an observation arc of only 4 days, the asteroid has a [[Uncertainty Parameter U|poorly determined orbit]]. It is already known that there is no risk of an Earth [[Impact event|impact]] before 2098. The power of such an [[air burst]] would be somewhere between the [[Chelyabinsk meteor]] and the [[Tunguska event]] depending on the actual size of the asteroid. The [[Curve fitting|nominal]] orbit shows that on 16 September 2014 the asteroid could have passed just inside one [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distance]] from Earth, but the orbital uncertainties show that it could have passed as much as {{convert|0.1|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. On 9 September 2014 the [[full moon]] may have only be 15 degrees from the 20th magnitude asteroid, making it difficult to detect the asteroid. The asteroid was estimated to be brighter than magnitude 20 from 10 September until 16 September 2014. {{mp|2009 RR}} was not recovered during the 2014 approach and thus probably passed more than one lunar distance from Earth. == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type=last observation: 2009-09-15; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 4 days |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2009 RR) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2009RR |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate=30 March 2016}} {{cite web |title=MPEC 2009-R39 : 2009 RR |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=2009-09-11 |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K09/K09R39.html |accessdate=2014-01-13}} (K09R00R) {{cite web |title=Earth Impact Risk Summary: 2009 RR |publisher=NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/sentry/details.html#?des=2009%20RR |accessdate=2018-01-22}} {{cite web |type = last observation: 2009-09-15; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 4 days |title = JPL Close-Approach Data: (2009 RR) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2009RR;cad=1#cad |archiveurl = https://archive.today/20140805062943/http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2009RR;cad=1%23cad#cad |archivedate = 5 August 2014 |dead-url = no |accessdate = 2014-01-13 |df = dmy-all }} {{cite web |title = 2009RR Ephemerides for September 2014 |publisher = [[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url = http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2009RR&oc=500&y0=2014&m0=9&d0=9&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2014&m1=9&d1=17&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=days |archiveurl = https://archive.today/20140115202331/http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2009RR&oc=500&y0=2014&m0=9&d0=9&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2014&m1=9&d1=17&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=days |archivedate = 15 January 2014 |dead-url = no |accessdate = 2014-01-15 |df = dmy-all }} }} == External links == * {{JPL small body|id=3467062}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2014 in space}} {{Planetary defense}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2009 RR}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Potential impact events caused by near-Earth objects]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2014|20140916]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2009|20090911]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2012 UE|34}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2012 UE|34}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Pan-STARRS]] 1 | discovery_site = [[Haleakala Observatory|Haleakala Obs.]] | discovered = 18 October 2012
{{small|(first observed only)}} | mpc_name = {{mp|2012 UE|34}} | alt_names = | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 3 | observation_arc = (260 days) | aphelion = 1.2150 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.9956 AU | semimajor = 1.1053 AU | eccentricity = 0.0992 | period = 1.16 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (424 days) | mean_anomaly = 242.19[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.8482|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 9.6587° | asc_node = 198.48° | arg_peri = 18.409° | moid = 0.0002 AU (0.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]]) | mean_diameter = {{val|66|ul=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.20]])}}
{{val|130|u=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.05]])}} | rotation = | albedo = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 23.3 }} '''{{mp|2012 UE|34}}''' is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately 70 meters in diameter. It was first observed on 18 October 2012, by [[Pan-STARRS]] at [[Haleakala Observatory]] on the island of Maui, Hawaii, in the United States. The object was removed from the [[Sentry Risk Table]] on 29 December 2013. Due to its presumed small size, it does not qualify as a [[potentially hazardous asteroid]], despite its low Earth [[MOID]] of 0.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]]. == Description == {{mp|2012 UE|34}} is an [[Apollo asteroid]], which are [[List of Earth-crossing minor planets|Earth-crossers]] and the largest subgroup in the [[near-Earth object]] population. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 1.00–1.22 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 14 months (424 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 1.11 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.10 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 10[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with its official first observation at Haleakala in October 2012. === Close encounters === {{mp|2012 UE|34}} passed about {{convert |0.002 |AU|km mi |abbr=on |lk=off |order=flip}} from Earth on 8 April 1991. On 8 April 2041, the asteroid will pass about {{convert |0.0007 |AU|km mi |abbr=on |lk=off |order=flip}} from Earth. For comparison, the distance to the [[Moon]] is about 0.0026 AU (384,400 km). It has an exceptionally low [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] with Earth of {{convert|0.0002 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off}}, which translates into 0.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|Lunar distances]]. Despite this exceptionally low theoretical distance, the asteroid is not listed as a [[potentially hazardous asteroid]], due to its small size, represented by its proxy, an [[absolute magnitude]] of 23.3, which is too faint and above the defined threshold of 22 magnitude. {|class="wikitable collapsible collapsed sortable" |+H < 24 asteroids passing less than 1 LD from Earth !Asteroid !Date !Nominal approach distance (LD) !Min. distance (LD) !Max. distance (LD) ![[Absolute magnitude]] (H) !Size (meters) |-bgcolor=#c2c2c2 |{{mpl|(152680) 1998 KJ|9}} || 1914-12-31 || 0.606 || 0.604 || || 1.215 || 21.6 || 101–327 |} == Physical characteristics == Based on a generic magnitude-to-diameter conversion, {{mp|2012 UE|34}} measures 66 meters in diameter, for an absolute magnitude of 23.3 and an assumed [[Astronomical albedo|albedo]] of 0.20, which is typical for stony [[S-type asteroids]]. In the unusual case of being a [[C-type asteroid|carbonaceous asteroid]] with a low albedo of 0.05, {{mp|2012 UE|34}} may be as large as 130 meters in diameter. == Numbering and naming == This [[minor planet]] has not been numbered by the [[Minor Planet Center]] and remains [[List of named minor planets (numerical)|unnamed]]. == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2013-07-05 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2012 UE34) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3612847;cad=1 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 9 February 2018}} {{cite web |title = 2012 UE34 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2012+UE34 |accessdate = 9 February 2018}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid Size Estimator |publisher = CNEOS NASA/JPL |url = https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/tools/ast_size_est.html |accessdate = 9 February 2018}} {{cite web |title=Date/Time Removed |publisher=NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/removed.html}} }} == External links == * [https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K12/K12U61.html MPEC 2012-U61 : 2012 UE34], ''[[Minor Planet Electronic Circular]]'', 20 Oct 2012 * {{YouTube|id=8M_27st1ZCI|title=Minor Planet Center: Asteroid Hazards, Part 3: ''Finding the Path''}} {{small|(min. 5:38)}}, includes discussion of {{mp|2012 UE|34}} * [http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.0&n=2012UE34 {{mp|2012 UE|34}}] at NEODyS-2 * [http://earn.dlr.de/nea/K12U34E.htm Physical facts sheet], European Asteroid Research Node (EARN), 18 Oct 2012 * [https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/lists/t_apollos.html List Of The Potentially Hazardous Asteroids (PHAs)], ''Minor Planet Center'' * {{JPL small body}} {{s-start}} {{s-bef|before={{mpl|99942 Apophis|}}}} {{s-ttl|title=Large [[Near-Earth object|NEO]] Earth close approach
([[List of record-setting asteroid close approaches to Earth#Asteroids|inside the orbit of the Moon]])|years=8 April 2041}} {{s-aft|after={{mpl|2005 WY|55}}}} {{end}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2012 UE34}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Discoveries by Pan-STARRS]] [[Category:Asteroids removed from the Sentry Risk Table]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 1991|19910408]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2012|20121018]]

{{Infobox event | title = | image = | image_size = | caption = | date = {{start date|2017|10|04}} | time = 20:07 local time (12:07 [[UTC]]) | place = [[Yunnan]], [[China]] | coordinates = {{coord|28.1|99.4|region:TH_type:event|display=inline,title}} | also known as = | cause = meteor
Impact energy: 0.54 [[TNT equivalent|kiloton]]
Radiated energy: 192 GJ[http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/fireballs/ Fireball and Bolide Reports] (JPL) | first reporter = | filmed by = | participants = | outcome = | reported deaths = | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | inquiries = | url = | notes = }} On October 4, 2017 around 8:07 PM local time, an extremely bright [[meteoroid]] fell over the northern [[Yunnan]] province of China, reaching maximum [[brightness]] roughly 37 kilometers above the ground. The 8-second [[superbolide]] was widely recorded, as it fell in the late evening on the [[Mid-Autumn Festival]], a fairly popular festival in China.{{cite news|title=Surprise Meteor Lights Up Harvest Moon Festival|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/10/full-moon-meteor-fireball-china-space-science/|accessdate=5 December 2017|publisher=National Geographic|date=9 October 2017}} ==Overview== Based on its incoming velocity (14.6 km/s) and energy, the original asteroid was likely between 2.2 and 3.6 meters across,{{cite web|title=Asteroid Impact Crater Calculator - calculates the effects of the impact of an object hitting the earth|url=http://convertalot.com/asteroid_impact_calculator.html|website=convertalot.com|accessdate=5 December 2017}} slightly smaller than the [[2015 Thailand bolide]], which fell about 2 years previously, several hundred miles to the south. This is the largest recorded meteor to fall over China since the 2000 bolide, which radiated about 262 [[Joule|gigajoules]] of energy compared to the 2017 event's 192. While it was only the 5th most energetic impact event of 2017, it was the largest one to occur over land, and a populated area no less. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Modern impact events}} {{2017 in space}} [[Category:2017 in China]] [[Category:Modern Earth impact events]] [[Category:Meteoroids]] [[Category:2017 in space]] [[Category:October 2017 events in China]]

[[Image:5Y3GT.jpg|thumb|right|200px|5Y3GT by General Electric, circa 1960 (right) and Sovtek, circa 2005 (left)]] The '''5Y3''' is a medium-power directly heated full-wave [[rectifier]] [[vacuum tube]] introduced by [[RCA]] in 1935. It has found wide use in tube radios and early [[guitar amplifiers]] (of the [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] Champ type). It is virtually identical, electrically, to the older four-pin type 80 tube, but with an [[octal]] [[valve base|base]]. 5Y3G, 5Y3GT, and 5Y3WGTA are variants with essentially the same specification;<ref>[http://www.r-type.org/static/web05.htm National Valve Museum, equivalents beginning "5"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203211801/http://www.r-type.org/static/web05.htm |date=February 3, 2012 }}</ref> the 6087 is similar and a plug-in replacement, but with indirectly heated cathode.
RCA and other manufacturers later introduced many similar 5V rectifier tubes of both higher and lower current and voltage rating, including the 5V3, 5W3, 5X3, 5Z3, 5U4, 5Z4, GZ32, and GZ34.
As for a suitable replacement, the 5Y4G has same specifications as the 5Y3G but with a different pin out.<ref>[http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/155/5/5Y3GT.pdf 5Y3GT data]</ref><ref>[http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/049/5/5Y4GT.pdf 5Y4GT data]</ref>
[[Sovtek]] in Russia manufacture a 5Y3GT with similar specifications,<ref>[http://www.svetlana.com/ProductHighLight.aspx?ProId=155 New Sensor: brief Sovtek 5Y3GT specification. Filament current misprinted; actually 2A.]</ref> but indirectly heated, and with higher maximum current at 140 instead of 120 mA.{{dubious|date=August 2016}}
==See also== *[[List of vacuum tubes]]
== References == <References/>
==External links== * http://www.r-type.org/pdfs/5y3gt.pdf General Electric datasheet *http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/127/5/5Y3GT.pdf Tung-Sol 5Y3GT datasheet *http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/049/5/5Y3G.pdf RCA 5Y3G & 5Y3GT datasheet *http://www.svetlana.com/pdf/sovtek/5y3gt-sovtek.pdf Sovtek 5Y3GT datasheet
[[Category:Vacuum tubes]] [[Category:Guitar amplification tubes]]
{{electronics-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Bonn Challenge''' is a global effort to restore 150 million hectares of the world's degraded and deforested lands by 2020. It was hosted and launched by Germany and the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN) in [[Bonn]] on 2 September 2011, in collaboration with the Global Partnership on Forest/Landscape Restoration and targets delivery on the [[Rio Convention]]s and other outcomes of the 1992 [[Earth Summit]].<ref name="IUCN policy" /> As at 2013 over 20 million hectares of land had been pledged for restoration from countries including [[Brazil]], [[Costa Rica]], [[El Salvador]], [[Rwanda]], and the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web|title=On the Road to the Bonn Challenge|url=http://www.forestlandscaperestoration.org/resource/road-bonn-challenge|publisher=Global Partnership on Forest/Landscape Restoration|accessdate=6 March 2014}}</ref> [[South Korea]], Costa Rica, [[Pakistan]], [[China]], [[Rwanda]] and Brazil have embarked on successful landscape restoration programmes.<ref name="3 News">{{cite news|title=Governments sign up to Bonn Challenge restoring degraded land|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Governments-sign-up-to-Bonn-Challenge-restoring-degraded-land/tabid/1160/articleID/258215/Default.aspx|accessdate=7 March 2014|newspaper=3 News|date=19 Jun 2012}}</ref>
The IUCN estimates that fulfilling the goals of the Bonn challenge would create approximately $84 billion per year in net benefits that could positively affect income opportunities for rural communities.<ref name="IUCN policy">{{cite web|title=IUCN's POLICY BRIEF ON THE ECONOMICS OF FOREST LANDSCAPE RESTORATION|url=http://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/policy_brief_on_forest_restoration_2.pdf|publisher=IUCN|accessdate=7 March 2014}}</ref> It is also estimated that a reduction of the current [[carbon dioxide]] emissions gap by 11-17% will be achieved by meeting the challenge.<ref name=IUCN>{{cite web|title=Bonn Challenge and Landscape Restoration|url=http://www.iucn.org/about/work/programmes/forest/fp_our_work/fp_our_work_thematic/fp_our_work_flr/more_on_flr/bonn_challenge/|accessdate=7 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307155230/http://www.iucn.org/about/work/programmes/forest/fp_our_work/fp_our_work_thematic/fp_our_work_flr/more_on_flr/bonn_challenge/|archivedate=7 March 2014|df=}}</ref> [[Pakistan]]'s [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] pledge has the distinction of being the first sub-national pledge, the first pledge to be fully implemented, and the first pledge to be increased.|<ref>{{cite web|title=Pakistan (KPK)|url=http://www.bonnchallenge.org/content/pakistan-kpk|publisher=IUCN|accessdate=26 Nov 2018}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Forest restoration]]
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Forest conservation]] [[Category:Forestry initiatives]] [[Category:Climate change mitigation]]
{{Environment-stub}}
