revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Mahmudur Rahman | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = Mahmudur Rahman at seminar in [[Sylhet]], 2011 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1953|07|06}} | birth_place = Comilla, Bangladesh | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = Dhaka, Bangladesh | nationality = Bangladeshi | other_names = | citizenship = | education = Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology;
Dhaka University | alma_mater = | occupation = Journalist; owner and editor of the ''daily amar desh'' | years_active = Editor since 2008 | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Editor of pro-BNP newspaper ''Daily Amar Desh'' | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = Bangladesh National Party (BNP){{cite news |date=20 August 2010 |title=Bangladeshi editor sentenced for contempt |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/newspapers/2010/08/court-bangladesh-amar-contempt |newspaper=The New Statesman |accessdate=16 March 2013}} | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_status = | spouse = Firoza Khan | partner = | children = | parents = Mahmuda Begum (mother) | relatives = | awards = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Mahmudur Rahman''' ({{lang-bn|মাহমুদুর রহমান }}; born 6 July 1953) is the one of the owners and acting editor of one of [[Bangladesh]]'s [[Bengali language|Bengali]] daily newspapers, ''[[Amar Desh]]''. He is also an engineer and businessman. Established in business, Mahmudur Rahman was appointed the executive chairman of the National Investment Board in 2002, and then elevated to national energy adviser in 2005. In both positions, Rahman set high goals for attracting foreign investments and increasing energy capacity in Bangladesh. While he had success in attracting foreign investors, he also took controversial steps such as increasing petrol prices or developing open-pit mines that set off protests across the country. Since the restoration of civilian government and the [[Awami League]] victory in 2008, Rahman has been a strong critic of the government through his newspaper. Party and government officials have reacted by charging him with [[defamation]] and [[sedition]] cases more than 50 times since 2009 to 2013. He is the only person to be sentenced for contempt by the [[Bangladesh Supreme Court]].{{cite news |date=19 August 2010 |title=Mahmudur jailed for contempt of court |url=http://ns.bdnews24.com/details.php?id=171085&cid=2 |newspaper=bdnews24.com |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FNaeZq5U?url=http://www.newstatesman.com/newspapers/2010/08/court-bangladesh-amar-contempt |archivedate=25 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=21 March 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |date=17 March 2011 |title=Mahmudur Rahman freed |url=http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=9dd28afc29684433c16b3855ae3cb9b6&nttl=2011032016886 |newspaper=Banglanews24.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316024133/http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=9dd28afc29684433c16b3855ae3cb9b6&nttl=2011032016886 |archive-date=16 March 2012 |accessdate=9 January 2013}}{{cite web|title=Editor, journalist jailed for contempt in Bangladesh |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |date=20 August 2010 |accessdate=16 March 2013 |url=http://www.cpj.org/2010/08/editor-journalist-jailed-for-contempt-in-banglades.php}} International human rights groups and press organisations have characterised the government's actions against him as judicial harassment.{{cite news |first1=Elizabeth |last1=Yuan |first2=Farid |last2=Ahmed |date=1 March 2013 |title=Seeking war crimes justice, Bangladesh protesters fight 'anti-Islam' label |work=CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/27/world/asia/bangladesh-protests/ |accessdate=16 March 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.fidh.org/Ongoing-judicial-harassment,9477 |title=Ongoing judicial harassment against Mr. Mahmudur Rahman – BGD 001 / 0610 / OBS 075.3 |date=8 April 2011 |publisher=International Federation for Human Rights |accessdate=16 March 2013}} Critics have said he has misrepresented bloggers and activists associated with the [[2013 Shahbag protests]] and contributed to widespread religious tensions and civil unrest.{{cite news |date=24 February 2013 |title=Protesters vow to resist anti-lib forces |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2900317731.html |work=The New Nation |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} ==Early life== Mahmudur Rahman was born in [[Comilla]], Bangladesh,{{cite news |first=Reazul |last=Bashar |date=11 April 2013 |title=Always in headlines |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/11/always-in-headlines |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=11 April 2013}} his mother is Mahmuda Begum. He received his Bachelor of Chemical Engineering in 1977 from [[BUET|Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology]].{{cite web |url=http://www.buet.ac.bd/che/Alumni_by_Year.htm |title=ChE Dept: List of ChE Alumni by Year |website=Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823045707/http://www.buet.ac.bd/che/Alumni_by_Year.htm |archive-date=23 August 2008 |accessdate=17 March 2013}} After working in engineering in Japan, he returned to earn a graduate diploma in Ceramic Engineering. He also earned an [[M.B.A.]] from the [[Institute of Business Administration, University of Dhaka|Institute of Business Administration]], [[Dhaka University]]. He married Firoza Khan, the daughter of [[Harunur Rashid Khan Monno]]. The latter has been politically affiliated with the BNP since independence. ==Business career== Rahman started his career as an operational engineer at [[The BOC Group|British Oxygen]], a major British-owned gas company. He also worked in Munnu Ceramics, Duncan Brothers, Shinepukur Ceramics, Beximco Group, and Padma Textile, including some years in Japan. After returning to Bangladesh, Rahman started and developed his own company, Artisan Ceramics Limited in 1999. It was the first bone china plant in the country and a technological breakthrough.{{cite news |date=23 August 2000 |title=Finance Minister draws attention to domestic market |url=http://www.bangla2000.com/news/archive/business/8-23-2000/news_detail1.html |newspaper=Bangla 2000 |accessdate=17 March 2013}} Artisan Ceramics was sold in 2013.{{cite news |first=Sajjadur |last=Rahman |date=25 August 2013 |title=Finlay makers buy Mahmudur Rahman's Artisan Ceramics |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/finlay-makers-buy-mahmudur-rahmans-artisan-ceramics/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=17 September 2013}} ==Political career== === National Investment Board === Rahman was appointed by the administration of [[Khaleda Zia]] as chair of the National Investment Board. In 2002, he described the obstacles to foreign investment in Bangladesh as the "five 'I's": "image, information, infrastructure, implementation and inefficiency" and committed the government to achieving change.{{cite news |date=17 October 2002 |title=Corruption, poor infrastructure repelling investment |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-68809887.html |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} He credited the opening of the power plant Meghna Energy Limited in Kanchpur, to the government's energy deregulation.{{cite news |date= 23 May 2002 |title=Independent power plant opens at Kanchpur |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-53194634.html |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} Between 2002 and 2003, foreign investment in Bangladesh increased from $52 million to US$121 million, an increase which Rahman said was the greatest in South Asia.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-99259908.html |title=Foreign investment doubles to US$121 million in Bangladesh: U.N. report |author=Julhas Alam |date=22 September 2004 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} In 2004, the United Nations reported that foreign investment in Bangladesh had reached a record US$460 million.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-113628605.html |title=Bangladesh receives record US$460 million in foreign direct investment in 2004, UN says |author=Julhas Alam |date=29 September 2005 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} Political unrest arose in 2004. On 21 August, grenade attacks at an opposition Awami League rally killed 20 and injured around 300 others. General strikes against Prime Minister Khaleda Zia's government were held regularly throughout the end of the year. Rahman criticized both sides, saying that such political violence and unrest threatened much-needed foreign investment, and the government had to provide security.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-98559568.html |title=Foreign investment threatened by unrest in Bangladesh, official says |author=Julhus Alam |date=31 August 2004 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} He offered his resignation in December 2004, reportedly over a dispute with officials in the [[Prime Minister's Office (Bangladesh)|Prime Minister's Office]], but Zia declined to accept it. Rahman continued in the post for the remainder of his "two-year contractual obligation."{{cite news |date=7 December 2004 |title=BOI chief's resignation not accepted |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-103215556.html |location=Dhaka |work=The Independent |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} Rahman's goal was to attract US$1 billion in investment to Bangladesh while in office.{{cite news |date=11 March 2005 |title=Bangladesh expects investment rise |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2005/03/200841013483295819.html |work=Al Jazeera |archivedate=22 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJoFmJ90?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2005/03/200841013483295819.html |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}} He said that Bangladesh's infrastructure needed improvement. The government encouraged foreign investment in infrastructure through a "build-own-transfer" model.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-106265312.html |title=Bangladesh targets US$1 billion in foreign investment in 2006 |author=Julhas Alam |date=11 March 2005 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} In May 2005, Rahman announced a deal with the US company [[Vulcan Inc.]] to invest $1.6 billion in new power and fertiliser plants, projected to increase Bangladesh's energy capacity by nearly 50 percent.{{cite news |date=6 May 2005 |title=Bangladesh gets $1.6bn investment |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2005/05/2008410111252757113.html |work=Al Jazeera |accessdate=22 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJoROPKo?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2005/05/2008410111252757113.html |deadurl=no |archivedate=22 March 2013}} In August 2005, Rahman sued five members of the [[Centre for Policy Dialogue]], a private think tank, for [[defamation]] after they criticised his investment policy. He said they had made "disgraceful, false and fabricated statements". The ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' said the suit and issuance of related arrest warrants, was an example of "persecution of intellectuals critical of the government" and the persons sued were renowned in their field.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1092377531.html |title=Arrest warrants against Zia government critics |date=10 August 2006 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} === Energy Adviser === The June 2005 explosion at [[Niko Resources]]' Tengratila Gas Field in [[Sunamganj District]], was the second during the project to revive the Chattack field. Against accusations that Niko had bribed Energy Adviser Mosharraf Hossain, he resigned.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-134172580.html |title=Bangladesh—a second blowout has hit the Niko Resources project to revive the Chattak natural gas field |date=4 July 2005 |work=Petroleum Intelligence Weekly |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-110446953.html |title=Villagers flee homes as fire burns at Bangladesh gas field |date=25 June 2005 |publisher=Associated Press Worldbeam {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} Rahman was named to succeed him.{{cite web |url=http://www.energybangla.com/index.php?mod=article&cat=SomethingtoSay&article=733 |title=Mahmudur Rahman and His Energy Vision |last=Saleque |first=Khondkar Abdus |date=7 June 2008 |website=Energy Bangla |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009105007/http://www.energybangla.com/index.php?mod=article&cat=SomethingtoSay&article=733 |archive-date=9 October 2011 |accessdate=9 January 2013}} In August 2005, he announced completion of a deal with the British oil company Cairn Energy to explore oil and gas deposits offshore Bangladesh.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-112199177.html |title=Cairn Energy signs deal to explore gas and oil off Bangladesh |date=16 August 2005 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} The following month, Rahman participated in talks for a transborder natural gas pipeline from Burma's [[Arakan State]] to India, to pass through Bangladesh.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-112835089.html |title=India's petroleum minister visits Bangladesh; pipeline talks 'constructive' |date=5 September 2005 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} The deal was shelved in early October 2005 after Bangladesh asked for additional trade concessions, and Burma and India chose to develop a direct route between them.{{cite news |author=Subir Bhaumik |date=7 October 2005 |title=Indian gas deal to sideline Dhaka |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4318174.stm |work=BBC News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJsBgkKz?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4318174.stm |archivedate=22 March 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}} In 2006, Rahman accused Burma and India of having encroached on thousands of square miles of Bangladeshi territorial waters for natural gas exploration.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1414954061.html |title=Dhaka-Yangon to discuss maritime boundary, gas search |date=18 January 2008 |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} Rahman was involved in talks between the government and India's Tata Group in early 2006 over a $300 million proposal to build steel and fertiliser factories, as well as a power plant.{{cite news |author=Waliru Rahman |date=8 February 2006 |title=Bangladesh power deal in balance |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4694580.stm |work=BBC News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJpDaj1V?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4694580.stm |archivedate=22 March 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}} After the talks were unsuccessful, Rahman opened talks with Pakistan's [[Dawood Group]] in August 2006 on a more modest $30 million deal.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1101886051.html |title=After no to Tata, Bangladesh woos Pakistan's Dawood Group |date=21 August 2006 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} In September 2005, Rahman announced a 16 percent increase in petrol prices to aid the government-owned [[Bangladesh Petroleum Corporation]], due to the price increases for crude oil on world markets. The price hikes sparked protests in Dhaka, and the government adopted a five-day workweek to conserve energy. It expected that the private sector would follow the government example.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-112863286.html |title=Bangladesh introduces five-day workweek to save energy after oil price jump |date=6 September 2005 |publisher= Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} In June 2006, Rahman announced an additional one-third increase in petrol prices, as well as a 10 percent increase in diesel and kerosene prices, one of the largest fuel-price hikes in Bangladesh's history.{{cite news |date=8 June 2006 |title=Bangladesh fuel prices up by 10% |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/5061698.stm |work=BBC News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJoogoxM?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/5061698.stm |archivedate=22 March 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}} In late August 2006, protesters demanded Rahman's resignation as energy adviser and burned him in effigy in response to plans by the British corporation Asia Energy (now Global Coal, [[GCM Resources]]) to develop an open-pit coal mine in Phulbari, Dinajpur district.{{cite news |date=10 December 2010 |title=Massive demo in London in support of Phulbari movement against Asia Energy |url=http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=c876914f82ce54cb533b186afd41166e |newspaper=BanglaNews24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224172420/http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=c876914f82ce54cb533b186afd41166e |archive-date=24 February 2013 |accessdate=25 March 2013}} Activists said that the mine would cause environmental damage, threaten water supply, and displace up to 120,000 residents of the area, including the Shantal [[indigenous peoples]]. On the first day of protests, police killed six persons and 300 were injured in a massive protest of 30,000 people outside the local Asia Energy offices. The protests spread and the next day, twenty people were injured. Students at Dhaka University joined the effort. An estimated 70,000 people in total joined the protests across the country. As of December 2010, the mine was still being protested and the government had not awarded a contract for its development. In 2006 Rahman urged calm, saying, "This incident has sent the wrong message to foreign investors, which we cannot afford at all when we are struggling hard to woo more and more investment."{{cite news |date=27 August 2006 |title=Bangladesh coal mine protest spreads |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2006/08/200841015949276971.html |work=Al Jazeera |agency=Reuters |archivedate=22 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJnjVFTB?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2006/08/200841015949276971.html |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}}{{cite news |date=28 August 2006 |title=Strike urged over Bangladesh mine |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2006/08/2008410115343541975.html |work=Al Jazeera |agency=Reuters |archivedate=22 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FJnrDLCw?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2006/08/2008410115343541975.html |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}} === Caretaker government === [[Khaleda Zia]]'s government ended in October 2006 and, under the constitution, elections are supposed to take place within three months, or January 2007. That fall there was a fierce struggle among the numerous parties, 14 of which were part of an Awami League-alliance and several were allied with the BNP. The [[caretaker government]] was trying to bring all parties to the table to settle election questions amidst rising tensions and violence. ''Arab News'' noted when reporting the late November 2006 incident below, that "At least 40 people were killed and hundreds injured in clashes between rival parties since late October." As an ex-energy adviser, Rahman kept in touch with colleagues from the BNP in the government. On 24 November 2006, journalists and TV news reporters took photos of 44 BNP administration officials, some retired like Rahman and others incumbents, leaving Rahman's office after a midnight meeting; many tried to hide their faces. A spokesman from the Awami League said that the men were meeting to try to "rig" the scheduled January 2007 election for BNP and its allies. Rahman denied the charge, saying he was holding a "private party" for friends to see his new office. The Awami League (and allies) called for a boycott of the scheduled January 2007 elections, demanding electoral reform.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bangladesh-election/hasina-led-alliance-to-boycott-bangladesh-elections-idUSDHA15142020070103 Hasina-led alliance to boycott Bangladesh elections] In January 2007, the military led by [[Moeen U Ahmed|General Moeen]] took over the caretaker government, and imposed a [[state of emergency]].{{cite news |date=11 April 2007 |title=Politicians barred from visiting Khaleda Zia's residence |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200704110341.htm |newspaper=The Hindu |agency=PTI |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930222644/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200704110341.htm |archive-date=30 September 2007}} According to the then Presidential Adviser and Minister [[Mukhlesur Rahman Chowdhury]], Army Chief, Lt. Gen. Moeen was the main force in the military intervention and declaration by President Iajuddin Ahmed of a state of emergency on 11 January 2007.http://newsfrombangladesh.net/view.php?hidRecord=300534 ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thikana.net/?q=softwork/news_print&news_id=4&edition=12|title=Individual News Print - THIKANA|work=thikana.net}}{{cite web |url=http://mukhlesurrahmanchowdhury.webs.com/challengegenmoeen.htm |script-title=জেনারেল মঈন উ আহমেদ একজন জাতীয় বেঈমানঃ |trans-title= |website=Mukhlesur Rahman Chowdhury |language=bn |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418220754/http://mukhlesurrahmanchowdhury.webs.com/challengegenmoeen.htm |archive-date=18 April 2014}} Moeen and his associates selected that illegal government's Chief Advisor Dr. Fakhruddin Ahmed. Prof. Dr. Iauddin Ahmed continued as President. In March 2007, the caretaker government charged Khaleda Zia's two sons with corruption. In April, it announced a ban on politicians visiting the former prime minister, under the conditions of the emergency. The CTG also charged some of Zia's ministers with corruption. Also in April 2007, the CTG sued [[Sheikh Hasina]], leader of the Awami League, for graft. On 31 March 2007, the Establishment Ministry (under the caretaker government) announced that it had completed a three-person inquiry into the actions of some of the senior officials at the November 2006 meeting with ex-energy advisor Rahman. As a result, it reassigned 13 men out of office to positions as "officers on special duty" (OSD).{{cite news |date=31 March 2007 |title=Uttara 'conspiracy' officers found guilty, shunted out of office |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2007/03/31/uttara-conspiracy-officers-found-guilty-shunted-out-of-office |newspaper=BDNews24 |accessdate=24 March 2013}} Three of the men were "joint secretaries, four deputy secretaries and six senior assistant secretaries." The CTG in late 2008 began to prepare for an election that year. In October 2008, shortly before the December election, Rahman filed a complaint with the [[Anti Corruption Commission Bangladesh|Anti-Corruption Commission]] (ACC), against its chair General [[Hasan Mashhud Chowdhury]]. Rahman accused the BNP appointee of having misappropriated 224.1 million [[Bangladeshi taka|taka]] in a money-laundering scheme.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1669820591.html |title=ACC chairman ready to quit |date=4 December 2008 |work=The New Nation |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} After an investigation, on 19 March 2009, an ACC internal committee dismissed the complaint as "baseless and unmotivated". It noted that Rahman had failed to appear personally before the committee to provide evidence.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1665722021.html |title=ACC committee trashes Mahmudur's money-laundering complaint against General Mashhud as baseless, motivated |date=19 March 2009 |publisher=United News of Bangladesh {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} The election was held on 29 December 2008.{{cite news|title=Secret Talks Deepen Bangladesh Crisis |publisher=Arab News |date=27 November 2006 |accessdate=18 March 2013|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/291533}}{{cite news|title='Secret' meet of admin big wigs at ex-energy adviser's office |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=25 November 2006 |url= http://thedailystar.net/2006/11/25/d6112501128.htm}}{{cite news |date=26 November 2006 |title=JOF ultimatum to Iajuddin |url=http://bdnews24.com/politics/2006/11/25/jof-ultimatum-to-iajuddin |newspaper=[[bdnews24.com]] |accessdate=21 March 2013}} The Awami League and its Grand Alliance came to power with two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. In 2010, the Awami League government charged the 13 bureaucrats of what had become known as the "Uttara Conspiracy" with [[sedition]]. They received bail. At that time, eleven were still serving in the government and two had retired.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2058874481.html |title=HC upholds bail of 13 bureaucrats |date=16 June 2010 |work=The New Nation |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} ==Newspaper career== In 2008, Mahmudur Rahman bought the ownership of the Bengali-language, daily newspaper ''[[Amar Desh]],'' and was appointed acting editor. He has made it a leading opposition paper.{{cite news|first1=Alastair |last1=Carthew |first2=Simon |last2=Winkelmann |title=Bangladesh – Archive: Second Half 2010 |publisher=Konrad Adenauer-Stiftung |accessdate=17 March 2013 |url=http://www.kas.de/medien-asien/en/pages/11830/}}{{cite web|title=Bangladesh: Opposition Newspaper Raided by Police And Forced to Close |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=17 March 2013 |publisher=Article 19 |url=http://www.article19.org/resources.php/resource/1554/en/bangladesh:-opposition-newspaper-raided-by-police-and-forced-to-close}} On 28 December 2008, the day before national elections, an [[Awami League]] committee chairman accused Rahman of collaborating to print fake ballot papers with his presses in order for BNP supporters to rig the election.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1668489461.html |title=Mahmudur Rahman accused of making bid to rig votes: 4-party using militants in electioneering: AL |date=28 December 2008 |work=The New Nation |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} The Awami League-coalition won the 2008 election by an overwhelming margin, winning two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. It had promised to set up an International Crimes Tribunal to prosecute war crimes during the Bangladesh Liberation War. ===Legal disputes=== On 2 October 2009, ''Amar Desh'' reported that the [[Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission]] had hired Indian employees, and that their presence threatened state security. The BTRC sued the paper for defamation on 28 October, noting that the Indian nationals had been appointed by the United Nations, rather than the commission.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1888589451.html |title=Amar Desh authorities sued by state-run BTRC; Court summons Desh editor, publisher, 2 reporters |date=28 October 2009 |publisher=United News of Bangladesh {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=22 March 2013}} In January 2010, the energy minister, Tawfik-e-Elahi Chowdhury, sued ''Amar Desh'' for defamation over a December 2009 article alleging that he and Sajeeb Wazed Joy Hasina, the son of Prime Minister [[Sheikh Hasina]], had received bribes from [[Chevron Corporation]] to secure contracts in Bangladesh.{{cite news |date=19 January 2010 |title=Tawfik sues Amar Desh |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/01/19/tawfik-sues-amar-desh |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=15 March 2013}}{{cite news |date=28 December 2009 |title=Amar Desh newsmen sued in Jhenaidah, Gaibandha |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2009/12/28/88043.html |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Financial Express |accessdate=15 March 2013}}{{cite news |last=Greenslade |first=Roy |date=3 June 2010 |title=Bangladesh newspaper closed down |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2010/jun/03/press-freedom-bangladesh |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=15 March 2013}} Three days after the story was published, the reporter was physically attacked by unknown persons.{{cite web |url=http://www.ifj.org/assets/docs/141/155/76fdc8d-94b2e9b.pdf |title=Battle for Democracy: Press Freedom in South Asia, 2009–2010 |publisher=International Federation of Journalists |page=12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326160425/http://www.ifj.org/assets/docs/141/155/76fdc8d-94b2e9b.pdf |archive-date=26 March 2013}} Also in response to the article on Hasina and Chowdhury, Awami League members had already filed 24 defamation charges against ''Amar Desh'' before the energy minister did. [[Reporters Without Borders]] reported that on 1 June 2010, the government sent more than 100 police to arrest Rahman and close down the paper's printing press. National media also carried news of the paper's shutdown and editors' arrest.{{cite news |date=1 June 2010 |title=Govt closes Amar Desh |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/06/01/govt-closes-amar-desh |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=15 March 2013}}{{cite news |date=2 June 2010 |title=Amar Desh shut |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=141097 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=15 March 2013}} According to Reporters without Borders, Mohammad Hasmat Ali, publisher of ''Amar Desh'', the previous day had been taken by the National Security Intelligence (NSI), interrogated, and forced to sign two blank pieces of paper. NSI agents later filled these in with the following statements: # Ali claimed still to be the newspaper’s publisher after having transferred ownership to Rahman’s media company, and # he wanted to sue Rahman for fraud. The press organisation said that the NSI appeared to intend to "trap both men in order to have the newspaper's licence withdrawn under the 1973 press law." Several days later, the leaders of around 25 newspapers in Bangladesh signed a letter which demanded that the ban on ''Amar Desh'' publication be rescinded.{{cite news |date=5 June 2010 |title=Editors demand lifting of Amar Desh ban |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/06/05/editors-demand-lifting-of-amar-desh-ban |newspaper=bdnews24 |accessdate=15 March 2013 }} Different government entities filed a total of four charges against Rahman: two by police for an altercation that arose when they shut down the printing press and newspaper offices; one for sedition for allegedly publishing posters and publicity material for [[Hizb-ut-Tahrir]], a banned [[Islamist]] group; and one for fraud based on his publisher's signed statement. Rahman was remanded into custody for eight days.{{cite news |date=8 June 2010 |title=Bangladesh newspaper editor is charged with sedition |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10265003 |work=BBC News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FKoHPpdu?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10265003 |archivedate=23 March 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-231467376.html |title=Mahmudur granted bail in 4 cases |date=13 July 2010 |work=The New Nation |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} On 12 June, the High Court stayed the ban on ''Amar Desh'' operations, allowing it to resume publication.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2056572401.html |work=The New Nation |date=12 June 2010 |title=Amar Desh resumes publication |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} On 17 June 2010, Rahman's attorneys released his statement asserting torture during police custody.[http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2010/06/mahmudur-rahman-torture-bangladesh/ "Bangladesh: Mahmudur Rahman torture claim"], Index on Censorship, 17 June 2010, accessed 25 March 2013 Rahman was released on bail in mid-July. On 12 October 2010, the government deferred the sedition case.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-239134739.html |title=Sedition case against Mahmudur deferred |date=12 October 2010 |work=The New Nation |accessdate=22 March 2013 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} Rahman was acquitted of the other charges, a verdict upheld by the Appeals Court.{{cite news|date=18 July 2010 |title=No bar to Amar Desh republication |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/07/18/no-bar-to-amar-desh-republication |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=15 March 2013}} In August 2010, the Supreme Court of Bangladesh sentenced Rahman to six months for contempt of court for a 21 April 2010 ''Amar Desh'' article, which said the top court was pro-government. Rahman is the only person ever sentenced for contempt by the Bangladesh Supreme Court. The Supreme Court had a separate, pending charge for contempt for a 10 May article but withdrew it.{{cite news |date=18 August 2010 |title=Amar Desh article 'undermines people's trust' |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/08/18/amar-desh-article-undermines-people-s-trust |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=7 April 2013}} International human rights groups described the government's cases against ''Amar Desh'' as "legal harassment". Reporters Without Borders released a statement saying, {{quote|The Awami League government is clearly unable to tolerate criticism from this opposition newspaper and, in particular, its coverage of the controversial award of energy contracts to foreign companies. Rahman was an advisor in these matters in the last BNP government and his revelations are damaging for the government.{{cite web|title=Opposition daily closed, force used to arrest editor |publisher=Reporters Without Borders |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2013 |url=http://en.rsf.org/opposition-daily-closed-force-used-02-06-2010,37648.html}} }} On 17 March 2011, Mahmudur Rahman was freed from prison. Many national figures arrived to welcome his release, including the film maker [[Chashi Nazrul Islam]], writer [[Farhad Mazhar]], journalist Abdul Hye Shikdar, and former Inspector-General of Police M.A. Quayum.{{cite news |date=11 March 2011 |title=Mahmudur Rahman released from jail |url=http://www.daily-sun.com/index_test.php?view=details&type=daily_sun_news&pub_no=160&cat_id=3&menu_id=1&news_type_id=1&index=9&archiev=yes&arch_date=18-03-2011 |location=Dhaka |newspaper=Daily Sun}}{{dead link|date=January 2013}} ===Bangladesh International Crimes Tribunal=== In fulfilment of its campaign promises, the Awami government initiated a Bangladesh International Crimes Tribunal to bring justice related to war crimes committed during the Bangladesh liberation war in 1971. Less than a month after Rahman's release, on 28 March 2011 a judge issued an arrest order for him and two other journalists for defamation charges related to an April 2010 article reporting that certain Awami Party leaders of Kotalipara and their relatives were on the war crimes suspects' list of the International Crimes Tribunal.{{cite news |date=28 March 2011 |title=Arrest warrant against Mahmudur Rahman |url=http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=b86b8c4fa6f55a31dd1964bd374d654f&nttl=2011032917596 |newspaper=banglanews24.com |accessdate=11 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130628171431/http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=b86b8c4fa6f55a31dd1964bd374d654f&nttl=2011032917596 |archivedate=28 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }} The judge issued the arrest order for the three journalists because they failed to appear in court; but they had notified him of an earlier case requiring them to be in a Dhaka court the same day. Journalist organisations criticized the arrest order, saying a person could not appear before two courts the same day. They said that the government was disregarding the 2 February 2011 legislation passed by Parliament, which had "nullified the provision of issuing arrest warrants against newsmen in defamation cases."{{cite news |date=28 March 2011 |title=Fresh arrest warrant against Mahmudur issued |url=http://newagebd.com/newspaper1/archive_details.php?date=2011-03-28&nid=13346 |newspaper=New Age |accessdate=9 April 2013 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} By this time, Mahmudur Rahman had been subject to 49 legal cases under the Awami government, most for defamation.{{cite news |date=29 March 2011 |title=Mahmudur secures bail |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2011/03/29/mahmudur-secures-bail |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=9 April 2013}} On 14 December 2012, the government charged Rahman with sedition for publishing [[Skype]] conversations, illegally hacked by other parties, between Justice Mohammed Nizamul Huq,{{cite news |date=24 December 2012 |title=Nirmul leader demands punishment for Skype 'hacking' |url=http://www.bdnews24.com/details.php?id=238720&cid=3 |newspaper=bdnews24.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121227141227/http://www.bdnews24.com/details.php?id=238720&cid=3 |archive-date=27 December 2012 |accessdate=20 March 2013}}{{cite news |date=4 January 2013 |title=No retrial |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=263749 |newspaper=The Daily Star}} chairman of Bangladesh's International Crimes Tribunal, and Ahmed Ziauddin, an international criminal law expert and war crimes activist based in Brussels.{{cite news |date=14 December 2012 |title=HC questions legality of hacking e-mail, Skype |url=http://newagebd.com/detail.php?date=2012-12-14&nid=33362#.UWfZ9qIyx8E |newspaper=New Age |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004142537/http://www.newagebd.com/detail.php?date=2012-12-14&nid=33362#.VjlUULerQ-V |archive-date=4 October 2013 |accessdate=12 April 2013}} The discussions had to do with the work of the Tribunal, and the material was published also in ''[[The Economist]]'' and another Bangladesh media outlet. Huq resigned shortly afterward because of the controversy.{{cite magazine |date=15 December 2012 |title=The trial of the birth of a nation |url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21568349-week-chairman-bangladeshs-international-crimes-tribunal-resigned-we-explain |magazine=The Economist |accessdate=16 March 2013}}{{cite news |date=13 December 2012 |title=Sedition case filed against Amar Desh editor, publisher |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/latest_news.php?nid=43158 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=9 January 2013}} After charges were filed, Rahman avoided arrest by spending the next months in his newspaper's offices, leaving only to seek anticipatory bail.{{cite news |title=I'm Ready to be Arrested: Mahmudur Rahman |publisher=tazakhobor.com |date=14 December 2012 |accessdate=17 March 2013 |url=http://tazakhobor.com/politics/2064-im-ready-to-be-arrested-mahmudur-rahman |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819133712/http://tazakhobor.com/politics/2064-im-ready-to-be-arrested-mahmudur-rahman# |archive-date=19 August 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In protesting the charges, [[Amnesty International]] said, "The government of Bangladesh must ensure that everyone, in particular journalists and editors, are free to express their views and opinion peacefully without being harassed, intimidated, detained or tortured."{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/bangladesh-journalist-faces-sedition-charges-2013-01-08 |title=Bangladesh newspaper editor at risk |date=8 January 2013 |publisher=Amnesty International |accessdate=9 January 2013}} The prosecutions and convictions by the International Tribunal have resulted in rising political tensions among some interests. [[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami|Jamaat-e-Islami]], the largest Islamist party, led a one-day strike that developed into violent riots when one of its top officials was convicted. The [[2013 Shahbag protests]], supported by many students and younger people, began 5 February 2013 in Dhaka after one of the men convicted of war crimes was sentenced to life imprisonment rather than death, as two others were. Protesters demanded that persons convicted of war crimes be sentenced to death, and Jamaat-e-Islami be banned from politics because of the violence of its followers. On 24 February, protest leaders called for the arrest of Mahmudur Rahman, accusing him of inciting communal violence and sedition because of ''Amar Desh'' coverage of bloggers and activists. Demonstrators said Rahman had reported "fabricated" news.{{cite news |date=23 February 2012 |title=Case against Mahmudur Rahman |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/23/case-against-mahmudur-rahman |newspaper=bdnews24 |archivedate=24 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FMT01qSC?url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/23/case-against-mahmudur-rahman |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}}{{cite news |date=23 February 2013 |title=BNP hints govt hand in Shahbagh protest |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/23/bnp-hints-govt-hand-in-shahbagh-protest |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=22 March 2013}} On 26 February, Home Minister [[Muhiuddin Khan Alamgir]] met with protesters and pledged to take measures against Rahman. In response, the editor has called the Shahbag movement "nothing but fascism".{{cite news |date=26 February 2013 |title=Mahmudur takes a jibe at protesters, press |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/26/mahmudur-takes-a-jibe-at-protesters-press |newspaper=bdnews24 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FMSivKyj?url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/26/mahmudur-takes-a-jibe-at-protesters-press |archivedate=24 March 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=22 March 2013}} In a 2013 interview earlier in February with ''Prime News'', Rahman had said, {{quote|Whenever the Awami League came to power it tried its best to gag the voice of media. After the country's independence, during 1972–75 period, the AL kept only four newspapers as its mouthpiece for the party campaign closing publication of all newspapers. This is the basic characteristics of the AL and at that time all eminent editors had to go to jail. For instance Enayetullah Khan, Irfanul Bari, [[Al Mahmud]], Aftab Ahmed – all had to go to jail.{{cite news |last=Hossain |first=Mohsin |date=1 February 2013 |title=Gagging media is an old habit of AL: Mahmudur |url=http://www.dailyprimenews.com/details.php?id=5980 |newspaper=Prime News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420055542/http://dailyprimenews.com/details.php?id=5980 |archive-date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=16 March 2013}} }} Islam-affiliated parties held large demonstrations on 6 April 2013, with protesters demanding a new blasphemy law with a penalty of death. The Prime Minister said she did not support such legislation.{{cite news|title=Tension flares over 'blasphemy' and free speech |work=Deutsche Welle |date=9 April 2013 |accessdate=9 April 2013 |url=http://www.dw.de/tension-flares-over-blasphemy-and-free-speech/a-16728459}} Noting that blasphemy laws covered "hurting religious sentiment," the government charged four bloggers of eleven it identified as posting anti-Muslim material. It said the law could be applied to ''Amar Desh'' and ''Daily Sangram'' for inaccurate December 2012 articles purportedly representing imams in Saudi Arabia.{{cite news |date=2 April 2013 |title=Steps if religious sentiments hurt: Ministers |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/02/steps-if-religious-sentiments-hurt-ministers |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=9 April 2013}}{{cite web|first=Bob |last=Dietz |title=Four bloggers arrested amid crackdown in Bangladesh |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |date=4 April 2013 |accessdate=9 April 2013 |url=http://www.cpj.org/2013/04/four-bloggers-arrested-amid-crackdown-in-banglades.php}}{{cite news |date=3 April 2013 |title=7 more bloggers to be arrested: Home minister |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/11-bloggers-identified-says-home-minister/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=9 April 2013}} In late February 2013, the bloggers and ''Amar Desh'' attacked each other in print and online. Reporters Without Borders and the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] have criticised both the legal harassment of Rahman and the arrest of bloggers as hampering freedom of the press in Bangladesh. ==April 2013 arrest== On 11 April 2013, Bangladesh Police finally arrested Rahman on charges of sedition related to the hacked Huq-Ziauddin conversations, other cyber-crimes, and inciting violence. They seized his electronics and storage devices. The court granted 13 days of remand for sedition and the other charges.{{cite news |date=11 April 2013 |title=Bangladesh opposition editor Mahmudur Rahman arrested |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22110132 |work=BBC News |accessdate=11 April 2013}}{{cite news|title=Bangladesh newspaper editor arrested in raid |newspaper=Al-Jazeera |date=11 April 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2013 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2013/04/2013411561842868.html}}{{cite news |date=11 April 2013 |title=Bangladesh Police Arrest Newspaper's Acting Editor |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_23002668/bangladesh-police-arrest-newspapers-acting-editor |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=11 April 2013}}{{cite news |date=12 April 2013 |title=Amar Desh acting editor held, put on 13-day remand |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Independent |url=http://www.theindependentbd.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=164395:amar-desh-acting-editor-held-put-on-13-day-remand&catid=129:frontpage&Itemid=121 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}{{cite news |date=11 April 2013 |title=Mahmudur Rahman arrested |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/11/mahmudur-rahman-arrested |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=11 April 2013}}{{cite news |first1=Syed Zain |last1=Al-Mahmood |first2=Tom |last2=Wright |date=11 April 2013 |title=Bangladesh Arrests Antigovernment Newspaper Editor |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323741004578415952473005678 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=11 April 2013 |subscription=yes}}{{cite news |date=11 April 2013 |title=Mahmudur Rahman on 13-day remand |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/amar-desh-acting-editor-mahmudur-held/ |newspaper=[[Daily Star (Bangladesh)|Daily Star]] |accessdate=11 April 2013}} The confirmed charges are as follows:{{cite news |date=12 April 2013 |title=Confusion over case against Mahumudur |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/12/confusion-over-case-against-mahumudur |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=12 April 2013}}{{cite news |date=12 April 2013 |title=Mahmud held under Penal Code: MKA |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/index.php?ref=MjBfMDRfMTJfMTNfMV8zXzE2NjE0Mg== |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Financial Express |accessdate=12 April 2013 }} * Section 124(a) of the Bangladesh Penal Code for [[sedition]]; * Article 57, Subsections 1 and 2 of the Cyber Crime and Information and Communication Act 2006, for "publishing fake, obscene or defaming information in electronic form", popularly known for aggravating "religious sentiments", which could carry a penalty of 10 years in prison; and * Article 58 of the Cyber Crime and Information and Communication Act 2006. That evening, the police closed down the ''Amar Desh''.{{cite news |date=11 April 2013 |title=Amar Desh press sealed |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/police-raids-amar-desh-press/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=12 April 2013}} Although the newspaper had been sealed, its declaration had not been suspended; the ''Amar Desh'' was distributed in limited editions for the next three days in Dhaka using another press.{{cite news|title=Amar Desh will resume publication after legal battle |newspaper=Daily Ittefaq |date=16 April 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2013 |url=http://www.clickittefaq.com/more-stories/amar-desh-will-resume-publication-after-legal-battle/}} Police raided the ''Daily Sangram'' and found evidence that it was printing ''Amar Desh''.{{cite news |date=13 April 2013 |title=Sangram press raided |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/13/sangram-press-raided |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=14 April 2013}} The government sued ''Sangram'''s publisher and editor, Abul Asad, and arrested 19 printers.{{cite news |date=14 April 2013 |title=Sangram Editor Sued (Update) |url=http://bdinn.com/news/sangram-editor-sued-update/|newspaper=BDINN |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819170329/http://bdinn.com/news/sangram-editor-sued-update/ |archive-date=19 August 2014 |accessdate=14 April 2013 }}{{cite news |date=14 April 2013 |title=19 Amar Desh press staff sent to jail |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/19-amar-desh-press-staff-sent-to-jail/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=14 April 2013}} It also filed charges against Mahmuda Begum, Rahman's mother, who had become the acting head of the newspaper in the absence of the editor.{{cite news |date=14 April 2013 |title=Sangram Editor sued |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/14/sangram-editor-sued |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=14 April 2013 |quote=Pro-BNP Amar Desh's Publication Division's Acting Chairman Mahmuda Begum has also been implicated in the case filed under the Printing Presses and Publications (Declaration and Registration) Act, 1973. Mahmuda is the mother of Amar Desh's Acting Editor Mahmudur Rahman.}}{{cite news |title=Khaleda Zia Visits Mahmudur Rahman Residence |date=14 April 2013 |accessdate=15 April 2013 |url=http://tazakhobor.com/national/3774-khaleda-zia-visits-mahmudur-rahman-residence |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416062205/http://tazakhobor.com/national/3774-khaleda-zia-visits-mahmudur-rahman-residence# |archive-date=16 April 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Syed Abdal Ahmed, an attorney and executive editor of the ''Amar Desh,'' said the Supreme Court's order from 2010 (?) was still in effect and prohibited the government from stopping the paper's publication. Information Minister Hasanul Haq Inu said ''Amar Desh'' could resume printing from another site once it had an order from Dhaka's magistrate.{{cite news |date=16 April 2013 |title='Amar Desh can be published from elsewhere' |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/16/amar-desh-can-be-published-from-elsewhere |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=16 April 2013 }} Farhad Mazhar, a journalist and family friend, had seen marks on Rahman's body that appeared to be signs of torture while in police confinement.{{cite news |date=20 April 2013 |title=Mahmudur Rahman tortured: family |url=http://www.newagebd.com/detail.php?date=2013-04-20&nid=46683#.UXjS8qIyx8E |newspaper=New Age |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709174758/http://newagebd.com/detail.php?date=2013-04-20&nid=46683#.UXjS8qIyx8E |archive-date=9 July 2013 |accessdate=25 April 2013}} Rahman's wife filed a petition asserting the police had tortured Mahmudur Rahman during the seven-day remand period related to sedition charges. The Supreme Court indicated it would respond to the writ on 21 April 2013.{{cite news |date=18 April 2013 |title=Order on Sunday |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/order-on-sunday/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=18 April 2013}} During his detention, Rahman started a [[hunger strike]] on 15 April to demand continued publication of the paper and the dropping of charges against his mother and the 19 printers.{{cite news |date=17 April 2013 |title=Mahmudur on 'hunger strike' |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/04/17/mahmudur-on-hunger-strike |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=18 April 2013}} In total, Rahman spent 13 days on remand. On 12 June, Mahmudur Rahman was remanded again for a further 3 days for the disturbances at 22 February protests that were alleged to be stirred up by ''Amar Desh'' reports.{{cite news |date=12 June 2013 |title=Mahmudur Rahman on remand |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/06/12/mahmudur-rahman-on-remand |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=13 June 2013}}{{cite news |date=13 June 2013 |title=Mahmudur Rahman remanded again |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/index.php?ref=MjBfMDZfMTNfMTNfMV8yXzE3Mjc5NQ== |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Financial Express |accessdate=13 June 2013 }} On 3 December, a court placed Rahman on a further six-day remand followed by confinement in jail.{{cite news |author=Md Sanaul Islam Tipu |date=9 December 2013 |title=Mahmudur sent to jail after remand |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/law-amp-rights/2013/dec/09/mahmudur-sent-jail-after-remand |newspaper=Dhaka Tribune |accessdate=15 December 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.fidh.org/en/asia/bangladesh/14345-bangladesh-guarantee-personal-integrity-and-release-acting-editor-of-amar |title=BANGLADESH: Guarantee personal integrity and release Acting Editor of Amar Desh, Mr. Mahmudur Rahman |date=5 December 2013 |website=International Federation for Human Rights |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126035712/http://www.fidh.org/en/asia/bangladesh/14345-bangladesh-guarantee-personal-integrity-and-release-acting-editor-of-amar |archive-date=26 January 2014 |accessdate=15 December 2013}} ===Reactions to arrest=== International human rights groups criticised the government's actions and called for the release of Rahman and the four bloggers. Protesting were [[Human Rights Watch]],{{cite web|title=Bangladesh: Crackdown on Bloggers, Editors Escalates |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=17 April 2013 |accessdate=17 April 2013 |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/04/15/bangladesh-crackdown-bloggers-editors-escalates|quote="By targeting peaceful critics in the media and blogosphere and promising more arrests, the government is abandoning any serious claim that it is committed to free speech. Bangladeshis should have the right to peacefully express their views, and the state should address these demands through the rule of law instead of embarking on politically motivated arrests."}}{{cite news |date=17 April 2013 |title=HRW asks govt to free Mahmudur, 4 bloggers |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/hrw-asks-govt-to-free-mahmudur-4-bloggers/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=17 April 2013}}{{cite web|title=Bangladesh Targeting Bloggers, Media Critics |publisher=Reason Magazine |date=16 April 2013 |accessdate=17 April 2013 |url=http://reason.com/24-7/2013/04/16/bangladesh-targeting-bloggers-media-crit}} the [[International Federation of Human Rights]] (FIDH) and the [[World Organization Against Torture]] (OMCT), which also asked the government to guarantee Rahman's security from torture;{{cite web|title=BANGLADESH: Release Interim Editor of Amar Desh, Mr. Mahmudur Rahman! |date=17 April 2013 |accessdate=17 April 2013 |publisher=FIDH.org |url=http://www.fidh.org/BANGLADESH-Release-Interim-Editor-13160 |quote=They "fear that he is currently at risk of torture and recall that the authorities have to fulfill their obligations under international human rights law to protect the right not to be subjected to torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment."}} and the [[Asian Human Rights Commission]].{{cite web|author=Asian Human Rights Commission |title=BANGLADESH: Intervene immediately to save the life of detained journalist Mr. Mahmudur Rahman |url=http://www.humanrights.asia/news/ahrc-news/AHRC-STM-076-2013 |publisher=Asian Human Rights Commission |date=11 April 2013 |quote= It "expresses serious concern about the deteriorating human rights situation in Bangladesh, most importantly concerning Mahmudur Rahman's safety whilst in state custody. Rahman's arrest is not only an attack upon media freedom but also is endangering the basic principles of democracy and the rule of law in Bangladesh."|accessdate=12 April 2013 }} In addition, press organisations supported release of the publisher and bloggers, and urged the government to protect freedom of the press. They included [[International Federation of Journalists]]{{cite news |date=12 April 2013 |title=Bangladesh Should Immediately Release Detained Editor, Bloggers |url=http://asiapacific.ifj.org/en/articles/bangladesh-should-immediately-release-detained-editor-bloggers |publisher=International Federation of Journalists |accessdate=12 April 2013 |quote="As the political confrontation between the ruling party and the opposition in Bangladesh escalates, the International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) calls for the immediate cessation of all hostile actions against journalists and free speech activists."}} and the Committee to Protect Journalists.{{cite web|title=Editor of pro-opposition daily arrested in Bangladesh |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |date=12 April 2013 |quote="We are concerned by the arrest of Mahmudur Rahman. In light of the highly politicized climate in Bangladesh, the press must be free to raise criticism and questions without fearing serious criminal charges."|accessdate=13 April 2013 |url=http://cpj.org/2013/04/editor-of-pro-opposition-daily-arrested-in-banglad.php}} Bangladesh politicians and activists generally responded in terms of their affiliations. Concerns expressed included that the government was increasing tensions, and opposition leaders urged freedom of the press. Representatives of the Awami League and those who opposed Rahman repeated accusations against him. [[Nurul Kabir]], editor of the competing daily, ''New Age,'' said, "I have serious disagreement with the editorial policy of Mahmudur Rahman and the most of the contents that his paper ''Amar Desh'' disseminates, but I have no doubt that the government has arrested him primarily because of his active support for the opposition political camps. In a democratic dispensation, this is unacceptable."{{cite news |first=Jason |last=Burke |date=16 April 2013 |title=Bangladesh simmers as Islamic conservatives and progressives clash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/16/bangladesh-hefazat-e-islam-women |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=16 April 2013}} After a Dhaka court accepted charges against 41 opposition politicians related to protests, BNP committee member MK Anwar spoke before a rally at the National Press Club. He said, "There's no peace in people's minds. Opposition leaders and workers are subjected to extreme torture. Now they (the Awami League government) have launched coercive acts against mass media. This government can't tolerate its opponents' views. They've closed down 'Amar Desh' printing press after arresting its acting editor Mahmudur Rahman."{{cite news |date=17 April 2013 |title=Court accepts charges against 41 opposition leaders |url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/index.php?ref=MjBfMDRfMTdfMTNfMV8zXzE2NjYyOQ== |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Financial Express |accessdate=17 April 2013}} On the other hand, a leader of the Shahbag protests repeated accusations of Rahman's misinformation. After more than a month of confinement, 15 editors signed a joint statement that demanded the release of Rahman, dismissal of cases against Rahman's mother and ''Daily Sangram'' for printing ''Amar Desh'' after Rahman's arrest, and an end to the ban on ''Amar Desh's'' publication, as well as similar bans from 5 May on broadcasters Diganta and Islamic TV.{{cite news |date=19 May 2013 |title=15 editors concerned |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/15-editors-concerned/ |newspaper=The Daily Star}} ==See also== * [[Blasphemy law in Bangladesh]] * [[Censorship in Bangladesh#Bangladesh|Censorship in Bangladesh]] * [[2012 ICT Skype controversy]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Nomāna, Aliullāha, ''Bijaẏī sampādaka Māhamudura Rahamāna'' (Language: Bengali), Ḍhākā : Mātr̥bhāshā Prakāśa, 2011. ==External links== * {{YouTube|Y749v0944Eo|BDINN: Interview with Mahmudur Rahman}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rahman, Mahmudur}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bangladeshi engineers]] [[Category:Bangladeshi journalists]] [[Category:Bangladeshi torture victims]] [[Category:Censorship in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Newspaper editors]] [[Category:Newspaper publishers (people)]] [[Category:People associated with energy]] [[Category:People from Comilla District]] [[Category:Torture in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology alumni]] [[Category:University of Dhaka alumni]] [[Category:People from Comilla]] [[Category:Bangladeshi newspaper editors]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/98.113.144.73|98.113.144.73]] ([[User talk:98.113.144.73|talk]]) to last revision by CalliopeMuse. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{speciesbox | image = Manilkara bidentata 1.JPG | image_caption = | genus = Manilkara | species = bidentata | authority = ([[Alphonse Louis Pierre Pyramus de Candolle|A.DC.]]) [[Auguste Chevalier|A.Chev.]]''Rev. Bot. Appliq.'' 1932, xii. 270. {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=787598-1 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Manilkara bidentata'' |quote=Notes: ''Mimusops bidentata'' |work=[[International Plant Names Index|IPNI]] |accessdate=December 25, 2009}} | synonyms = ''Mimusops bidentata'' A.DC.
''Mimusops globosa'' [[Karl Friedrich von Gaertner|C.F.Gaertn.]]
''Mimusops balata'' [[Hermann Crueger|Crueg.]] ex [[Griseb.]] : List sources :''Prodr. (DC.)'' 8: 204. 1844 [mid Mar 1844] {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=787862-1 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Mimusops bidentata'' |quote=Notes: =globosa |work=IPNI |accessdate=December 25, 2009}}''Suppl. Carp.'' 132 (t. 205). 1807 {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=787937-1 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Mimusops globosa'' |work=IPNI |accessdate=December 25, 2005}}{{ cite web |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-128391 |title=''Mimusops balata'' Crueg. ex Griseb. |work=[[The Plant List]] |publisher=[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]] and [[Missouri Botanical Garden]] |accessdate=August 4, 2011}} }} [[File:Manilkara bidentata MHNT.BOT.2010.6.32.jpg|thumb|''Manilkara bidentata'' - [[MHNT]]]] '''''Manilkara bidentata''''' is a species of ''[[Manilkara]]'' native to a large area of northern [[South America]], [[Central America]] and the [[Caribbean]]. Common names include '''bulletwood''',{{PLANTS|id=MABI5|taxon=Manilkara bidentata|accessdate=29 June 2015}} '''balatá''', '''ausubo''', '''massaranduba''', and (ambiguously) "[[Cow-tree (disambiguation)|cow-tree]]". Balatá is a large [[tree]], growing to {{convert|30–45|m|abbr=on}} tall. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate, elliptical, entire, and {{convert|10–20|cm|abbr=on}} long. The [[flower]]s are white, and are produced at the beginning of the rainy season. The [[fruit]] is a yellow [[Berry (botany)|berry]], {{convert|3–5|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter, which is edible; it contains one (occasionally two) [[seed]](s). Its [[latex]] is used industrially for products such as [[chicle]]. ==Uses== [[File:Logging Bulletwood Berbice-Guyana JK.JPG|thumb|left|Harvesting bulletwood in [[Guyana]]]] [[File:Tropenmuseum Royal Tropical Institute Objectnumber 1336-6 Zweep van balata.jpg|thumb|A whip handle of balatá, made before 1939]] The [[latex]] is extracted in the same manner in which sap is extracted from the [[rubber tree]]. It is then dried to form an [[Elasticity (physics)|inelastic]] rubber-like material. It is almost identical to [[gutta-percha]] (produced from a closely related [[southeast Asia]]n tree), and is sometimes called ''gutta-balatá''. Balatá was often used in the production of high-quality [[golf ball]]s, to use as the outer layer of the ball. Balatá-covered balls have a high spin rate, but do not travel as far as most balls with a [[Surlyn]]{{cite web|url=http://www2.dupont.com/Surlyn/en_US/|title=Ionomer Resin- DuPont™ Surlyn® - DuPont USA|website=2.dupont.com|accessdate=19 November 2017}} cover. Due to the nondurable nature of the material the golf club strikes, balatá-covered balls do not last long before needing to be replaced. While once favored by professional and low-handicap players, they are now obsolete, replaced by newer Surlyn and [[polyurethane|urethane]] technology. Today, Brazil is the largest producer of Massaranduba wood, where it is cut in the Amazon rainforest. The tree is a [[hardwood]] with a red heart, which is used for [[furniture]] and as a [[construction]] material where it grows. Locals often refer to it as '''bulletwood''' for its extremely hard wood, which is so dense that it does not float in water. Drilling is necessary to drive nailed connections. In trade, it is occasionally (and incorrectly) called "[[brazilwood]]". The fruit, like that of the related sapodilla (''[[Manilkara zapota|M. zapota]]''), is edible. Though its [[heartwood]] may present in a shade of purple, ''Manilkara bidentata'' should not be confused with another tropical tree widely known as "purpleheart", ''[[Peltogyne]] pubescens''.{{cite web |url=http://www.simonandshock.com/lumber.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106165409/http://www.simonandshock.com/lumber.htm |archivedate=2009-01-06 |df= }} This timber is being used to produce outdoor furniture and is being marketed as "Pacific Jarrah" in Australia. ==References== {{Commons category}} {{Wikispecies}} {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q804658}} [[Category:Manilkara|bidentata]] [[Category:Plants described in 1807]] [[Category:Trees of Brazil]] [[Category:Trees of Colombia]] [[Category:Trees of Dominica]] [[Category:Trees of Ecuador]] [[Category:Trees of French Guiana]] [[Category:Trees of Guyana]] [[Category:Trees of Hispaniola]] [[Category:Trees of Martinique]] [[Category:Trees of Suriname]] [[Category:Trees of Panama]] [[Category:Trees of Peru]] [[Category:Trees of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Trees of Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Trees of Venezuela]] [[Category:Trees of the Virgin Islands]] [[Category:Natural materials]] [[Category:Organic polymers]] [[Category:Rubber]] [[Category:Elastomers]]
